Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help,what's wrong with my TDD practice in my daily life?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=190530936; y=fl-D_oncqPdBXSFWN6PPoHO-jQCIu8R72LRwL4Mdo772e2ewNvHs

Hi Ilja, Michael,

On 9/12/07, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
> Ilja Preuss wrote:
>  >>There is duplication between the two strings but the refactoring
>  >>(putting the bits into a String array) removed the duplication at the
>  >>cost of readability. And, sometimes, readability trumps duplication.
>  >
>  >I would be *very* reluctant to accept that. I can't remember an instance
>  >where, when at first sight it seemed like accepting duplication improved
>  >readability, I couldn't come up with a more appropriate design that was
>  >both readable and duplication-free. Most often, I just missed an
>  >important insight.
>  >
>  It happens to me sometimes, but I'm reluctant to say that readability
>  trumps duplication sometimes because it is far to likely to be used as
>  an excuse.

I fully agree with the notion that we shouldn't accept duplication for
the very same reason as Michael pointed out. Yet, I sometimes do so.
Why?

Most of my work these days is spent coaching and working with teams
and individuals who are just adopting these techniques, sometimes
writing their very first unit tests. In doing this work I've more than
once found myself in a situation where the code base I'm looking at
doesn't reveal me a better design.

In other words, I'm not yet intimate enough to envision the
refactoring so I decide to leave it there for now--knowing that I'm
treading a dangerous path--and being on the lookout for a design that
doesn't exhibit that defect.


Lasse

-- 
Lasse Koskela
* Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
* Reaktor Innovations * http://www.ri.fi/en *
